entry.title: How to Create a 3D Tilting Card Effect in React Native
entry.summary: Recently, I came across a tutorial about how to create a 3D tilting card effect (with mouse tracking functionality) on Kevin Powell's YouTube channel [https://www.youtube.com/@KevinPowell]. Kevin used HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to create the markup, style the card, and implement the mouse tracking functionality, respectively. In this tutorial, we'll take

entry.title: What is a Remote Branch in Git? How to Check out Remote Branches from GitHub
entry.summary: Git is a free and open-source tool. Specifically, it is the most popular version control system used in software development today. Git allows you to keep track of and maintain different versions of a coding project. With Git, developers and technical teams can collaborate and work together on a project.

entry.title: ValueError: math domain error [Solved Python Error]
entry.summary: In mathematics, there are certain operations that are considered to be mathematically undefined operations. Some examples of these undefined operations are: * The square root of a negative number (âˆš-2). * A divisor with a value of zero (20/0). The "ValueError: math domain error" error

entry.title: Open-Closed Principle â€“ SOLID Architecture Concept Explained
entry.summary: The Open-Closed principle (OCP) is one the 5 SOLID design principles. It was popularized by the American computer scientist and instructor, Robert C. Martin (aka Uncle Bob) in a paper he published in 2000. The other 4 SOLID design principles are: * Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) * Liskov

entry.title: Why You Should Build Your Own Open-Source Project
entry.summary: After starting to learn about Open Source and making some good contributions during my first Hacktoberfest, I was moving ahead in my OSS journey. I wanted to have a big project of my own to which others could contribute. Fortunately, I had an idea for a project, and decided

entry.title: Python Remove Key from Dictionary â€“ How to Delete Keys from a Dict
entry.summary: Dictionaries are a useful data type in Python for storing data in a key-value format. And there are times when you might need to remove a particular key-value pair from a dictionary. You'll learn some dictionary basics, as well as how to delete keys, in this tutorial. How to

entry.title: The Difference Between Data Science and Data Engineering
entry.summary: I recently became very interested in Data Science and Data Engineering, especially how they compare and complement each other. I initially assumed Data Engineering was a subset of Data Science. But after extensive research I found out just how much the two fields differ. In this article, I'll discuss

entry.title: Git Diff and Patch â€“ Full Tutorial for Developers
entry.summary: Many of the interesting processes in Git like merging, rebasing, or even committing are based on diffs and patches. Developers work with diffs all the time, whether using Git directly or relying on the IDE's diff view. In this post, you will learn what Git diffs and patches are, their

entry.title: How to Use SQLite with Python
entry.summary: Databases are a crucial component in software development. After all, we need to collect data in a location where we can digitally access it for reading, writing, updating, and deleting. In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use SQLite with Python. Learning SQLite is a great way to learn how

entry.title: Getting Internationalization (i18n) Right With Remix And Headless CMS
entry.summary: This article will show you the impact of internationalization, its fundamental logic, how to approach it with Remix, and optionally, how to manage it more conveniently using a headless CMS.

entry.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 57 With Marcin Wichary: Whatâ€™s The Key To A Great Keyboard?
entry.summary: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast, we ask whatâ€™s the key to a great keyboard? Is this essential part of our daily toolkit easily overlooked? Vitaly Friedman talks to expert Marcin Wichary to find out.

entry.title: Keys To An Accessibility Mindset
entry.summary: An accessible product can be daunting to build as thereâ€™s so much nuance and technical depth to consider. In this article, Daniel Yuschick demonstrates three keys for approaching and developing accessible content without leaving you lost in the weeds.

entry.title: A Step-By-Step Guide To Building Accessible Carousels
entry.summary: Most carousels come along with usability and accessibility issues. To avoid these issues, this article addresses step-by-step design considerations as well as semantic requirements for carousels to be accessible. It is intended to create an in-depth understanding of the implementation and its impact on users.

entry.title: Putting Gears In Motion: Animating Cars With HTML And SVG
entry.summary: SVG `` provides a way to define how an element moves along a motion path. In this article, Paul Scanlon shares an idea of how to use it by animating race cars in an infinite loop as easy as one-two-three!

entry.title: Five Steps To Design Your Product With Powerful Storytelling
entry.summary: How to apply powerful storytelling to design a compelling and memorable digital experience on a landing page. A case study of the [Smart Interface Design Patterns landing page](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/).

entry.title: An Approach to Lazy Loading Custom Elements
entry.summary: Weâ€™re fans of Custom Elements around here. Their design makes them particularly amenable to lazy loading, which can be a boon for performance. Inspired by a colleagueâ€™s experiments, I recently set about writing a simple auto-loader: Whenever a custom â€¦ An Approach to Lazy Loading Custom Elements originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. entry.title: Discovering Primitive Objects In JavaScript (Part 1)
entry.summary: In the first part of the series, Kirill Myshkin covers some aspects of JavaScript that help bring objects closer to primitive values, which allow benefiting from common language features that arenâ€™t usually associated with an object, like comparisons and arithmetic operators.

entry.title: Healthcare, Selling Lemons, and the Price of Developer Experience
entry.summary: Every now and then, a one blog post is published and it spurs a reaction or response in others that are, in turn, published as blogs posts, and a theme starts to emerge. entry.title: Moving Backgrounds

entry.title: Picture Perfect: Meet Pixo, A Photo Editor For Your End Users
entry.summary: With so many image editing services available nowadays, itâ€™s good to have one good solution that is applicable for all websites and web apps that need to provide image editing as a feature. Hristo Chakarov explains how Pixo Editorâ€™s easy integration (just a few JavaScript lines) and rich API can save your time and improve your end usersâ€™ workflow.

entry.title: How Designers Should Ask For (And Receive) High-Quality Feedback
entry.summary: In this article, Andy Budd shares his way of requesting feedback: rather than sharing a linear case study that explains every design revision, the first thing to do would be to better frame the problem.

entry.title: The truth about CSS selector performance
entry.summary: Geez, leave it to Patrick Brosset to talk CSS performance in the most approachable and practical way possible. entry.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 56 With Veerle Pieters: How Has The Design Industry Changed?
entry.summary: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast we ask how has the design industry changed? Is technology making our work easier? Vitaly Friedman talks to veteran designer Veerle Pieters to find out.

entry.title: The Double Emphasis Thing
entry.summary: I used to have this boss who loved, loved, loved, loved to emphasize words. entry.title: How To Build A Magazine Layout With CSS Grid Areas
entry.summary: Web development, especially what you can do with CSS, has become increasingly complex. With the added capabilities of CSS Grid, it is now possible to achieve layouts that look like they were laid out by hand. Letâ€™s tackle a practical example of how to do something like that.

entry.title: A Fancy Hover Effect For Your Avatar
entry.summary: Do you know that kind of effect where someoneâ€™s head is poking through a circle or hole? The famous Porky Pig animation where he waves goodbye while popping out of a series of red rings is the perfect example, and â€¦ A Fancy Hover Effect For Your Avatar originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: UX Podcasts For Designers
entry.summary: Podcasts are a fantastic opportunity to get up close with the people who know their craft. In this post, we compiled podcasts that are bound to provide valuable insights into UX and new perspectives on the field. Perfect for a short coffee break or a long commute.

entry.title: How To Host A WordPress Site On Amazon Lightsail
entry.summary: Lightsail provides all the power we need to host our websites, as we are used to from AWS, but making it way easier than ever before. In this article, Leonardo Losoviz explores how to launch a WordPress site in Lightsail in a quick and easy way.

entry.title: Caching Data in SvelteKit
entry.summary: My previous post was a broad overview of SvelteKit where we saw what a great tool it is for web development. This post will fork off what we did there and dive into every developerâ€™s favorite topic: caching. So, â€¦ Caching Data in SvelteKit originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Understanding App Directory Architecture In Next.js
entry.summary: The new App Directory architecture has been the main character of the recent Next.js release, which keeps bringing up many questions. In this article, Atila Fassina explores the advantages and pitfalls of this new strategy and reflects on whether you should use it in production now or not.

entry.title: The Magic Of February (2023 Wallpapers Edition)
entry.summary: Do you need a little inspiration boost? Well, then our new batch of desktop wallpapers is for you. Designed by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for February 2023.

entry.title: How B2B Sales Help Us Understand Our Role As UX Designers Better
entry.summary: Throughout a customer journey (particularly in B2B), there will be interactions that are primarily between two people rather than a human and an interface. In this article, Paul Boag explains why you cannot improve the user experience without considering the entirety of the UX journey.

entry.title: Easy SVG Customization And Animation: A Practical Guide
entry.summary: Developers often feel discouraged from editing SVG markup and experimenting with SVG animations, thinking itâ€™s a significant time investment or they need to use a complex animation library to do so. In this article, Adrian showcases his favorite tricks, which make the process streamlined and fun.

entry.title: How To Build Strong Customer Relationships For User Research
entry.summary: In this article, Rachel walks you through various ways that product teams can utilize to build relationships with customers. She will share some tips and tricks from her experience that have helped her nurture customer relationships and build better products.

entry.title: Creating A High-Contrast Design System With CSS Custom Properties
entry.summary: Managing our colors can truly help people to access our content. In this article, Brecht de Ruyte takes a deep dive into how we can create a high-contrast system while maintaining a balance between designing something accessible and respecting the look and feel of a brand.

entry.title: Better ROI For Your Digital Products: Why Continuous Research Is Key
entry.summary: 57% of product professionals say that product research has a positive effect on customer satisfaction. 42% agree that it affects profitability. Imagine how much more successful your product would be if you did research continuously?

entry.title: Product Reviews And Ratings UX: A Designerâ€™s Guide
entry.summary: How do we design effective reviews and ratings? With a distribution chart, decimal scores, tags, recommendation score and unedited product photos.
